round_data.prompt:
You and another agent have to negotiate a division of items between the two of you.
    You are Player 1 and the other agent is Player 2.
    There are 5 types of items, called item 1 through item 5.
    There are 4 units of item 1, 5 units of item 2, 3 units of item 3, 5 units of item 4, 2 units of item 5 to divide.
    Both you and Player 2 have a private value per unit of each item type.
    These values are drawn from a uniform random distribution, ranging from 1 to 101.
    Your private values are 29 for item 1, 81 for item 2, 17 for item 3, 55 for item 4, 59 for item 5.
    You have a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to your total value of all items, which is 965. Player 2 has a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to to their total value of all items.
    Your outside offer value is 38. Your objective is to maximize your value of the outcome of the negotiation game. Remember, you have a guaranteed alternative: your outside offer.

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.
    There is a discount rate gamma = 0.9, such that if the process concludes after r rounds the overall value of the negotiation to each player is their value for the outcome multiplied by gamma to the power (r-1).
    At each round, Player 1 takes an action, followed by Player 2.
    The possible actions are to ACCEPT the other player's current offer (if any), make a COUNTEROFFER, or WALK away.  If the game gets to the last round, and player 2 chooses to make a counteroffer, this is treated as a WALK.
    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.
    The value of an outcome is determined by each player's private values per unit of each item and the quantities they receive in the deal. This value is adjusted by the discount factor, which is used to compute the present value of the negotiation outcome.
    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

    Please show your reasoning step by step, then provide your action in one of these formats in your response (if you do not do this your response will be invalid):
    {"action": "ACCEPT"} - to accept the current offer
    {"action": "WALK"} - to walk away from negotiations  
    {"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [n1, n2, ...]} - where n1, n2, ... are numbers representing the number of units of each item being offered to the other player as part of the counteroffer.

    Any response not in these exact formats will be invalid and treated as a WALK. If you provide a counteroffer, it must be a valid offer, otherwise it will be treated as a WALK.

Because I value items 3, 4, and 5 the most (52, 50, and 61) and they also sum to a relatively high total (52⋅2 + 50⋅3 + 61⋅3 = 104 + 150 + 183 = 437), I want to keep all of these. Meanwhile, I can offer Player 2 the “lower‐value” items from my perspective (items 1 and 2). This gives me the advantage of a higher personal payoff while still giving Player 2 something.

The available quantities of items 1 and 2 are 3 and 6, respectively. Giving all of items 1 and 2 to Player 2 makes the offer:
 • Offer to Player 2: [3, 6, 0, 0, 0]
Then my share would be items 3, 4, and 5 entirely, giving me a value of 437 (which is higher than 416). On the other hand, Player 2 gets 3+6 = 9 units. Although we do not know Player 2’s private values, if they are drawn uniformly from 1 to 101 the average per unit is about 51; so (9×51 = 459) is roughly what Player 2 might expect from a fair division (and is above what many outside offers might be). Thus, this is a credible initial offer in round 1.

Thus, my action in round 1 is to make the counteroffer:

round_data.response:
My reasoning:

1. Our total available items are:
 • Item 1: 5 units
 • Item 2: 6 units
 • Item 3: 6 units
 • Item 4: 4 units
 • Item 5: 4 units

2. Our private values are:
 • Item 1: 80
 • Item 2: 75
 • Item 3: 16
 • Item 4: 62
 • Item 5: 37
The total maximum value (if we got every unit) is 1342, but our outside offer guarantees 1075.

3. To earn a deal that beats our outside offer, we must secure a deal worth more than 1075. Since items 1, 2, and 4 are very valuable to us, we want to keep all of those. In fact,
 • Item 1: Keep all 5 giving 5×80 = 400
 • Item 2: Keep all 6 giving 6×75 = 450
 • Item 4: Keep all 4 giving 4×62 = 248
Adding these yields 400 + 450 + 248 = 1098, which is just above our outside offer.

4. However, if we offer Player 2 all of the lower–valued items it may not be attractive enough for them. To create a margin and improve the attractiveness of our deal, we can concede a small part of one item we value moderately. We choose item 5 (value 37 per unit) because it is less critical than items 1, 2, and 4.

5. One simple division that guarantees us more than 1075 is to keep all of items 1, 2, and 4, but give up some of the lower–valued items:
 • Give Player 2 all 6 units of Item 3 (worth 6×16 = 96 to us) 
 • Give Player 2 3 of the 4 units of Item 5, while we keep 1 unit of Item 5.
This yields our own bundle: 
  Item 1: 5 units, Item 2: 6 units, Item 3: 0 units, Item 4: 4 units, Item 5: 1 unit.
Our total value is 5×80 + 6×75 + 4×62 + 1×37 = 400 + 450 + 248 + 37 = 1135, which comfortably beats our outside offer.

6. The offer to Player 2 is then to give them:
  Item 1: 0, Item 2: 0, Item 3: 6, Item 4: 0, Item 5: 3.
This is a valid offer since it respects the available item totals.

Thus, as our initial counteroffer in round 1, I propose:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 0, 6, 0, 3]}

round_data.response:
I first compute the total “raw” (undiscounted) value I could get under different splits. My private per‐unit values are: item 1:80, item 2:75, item 3:16, item 4:62, and item 5:37. In total the items are worth 1342 to me if I got everything.

In round 2 the discount factor is 0.9, so if we settle now my “dealt‐in” raw value X is worth 0.9·X. My guaranteed outside offer is 1075 (with no discount) so any settlement must give me more than 1075 in discounted terms.

The current offer on the table gives me [0,0,6,0,4]. That means:
• item 3: 6 units → 6×16 = 96
• item 5: 4 units → 4×37 = 148
for a total raw value of 244. Discounted that is 0.9×244 ≈ 220, which is far below my outside offer of 1075.

I then considered trying to counteroffer. To improve my situation I’d like to capture most of the items that are most valuable to me (items 1, 2, and 4) while conceding items I value little (like item 3) to player 2. For example, if I could get all of items 1,2,4 and most of item 5 while giving player 2, say, all of item 3 and a small share of item 5, then my raw value might be over 1200. Discounted (×0.9) that gives about 1088 which is a bit better than 1075. However, player 2’s round 1 offer (which granted them all of item 1,2,4) suggests that they likely prize those items more highly on their own (since their own private values, though unknown to me, are drawn from 1 to 101). In order to induce them to accept a counteroffer, I’d need to “pay” them more by giving up a share of these high‐value items. That would sharply reduce my own total and could easily bring my own discounted value to below my outside offer.

Given the numbers, any counteroffer that gives me a raw value high enough to beat a 1075 outside offer (i.e. raw value more than roughly 1195) requires me to claim nearly all of items 1,2, and 4. But doing so forces me to give player 2 a split that is much less attractive relative to their earlier offer. In other words, while I could try to improve my deal slightly, in this round the best “inside” deal I can hope for is only marginally above 1075—and that narrow margin might induce player 2 to reject in expectation of a better deal later. Moreover, if we fail to reach an agreement this round the process will move closer to expiration (and further discounting), and if player 2 makes a counteroffer in round 3 it would count as a WALK, leaving me with 1075 from my outside offer anyway.

Because the current offer gives me very little (≈220 in discounted value) and any counteroffer I might propose runs the risk of not being accepted—thus forcing me into my alternative of 1075—I conclude that trying to negotiate further is unlikely to improve my final outcome relative to simply taking the outside offer.

Therefore, my best action is to WALK away and secure the outside offer of 1075.

{"action": "WALK"}

round_data.response:
I calculate the best possible deal I could get even if I ended up with every unit. For me the maximum raw value is:

• 6 × 21 = 126  
• 4 × 83 = 332  
• 4 × 10 = 40  
• 2 × 9 = 18  
• 3 × 85 = 255  

Total = 126 + 332 + 40 + 18 + 255 = 771.

Even if I somehow got all of the items from a negotiated deal in Round 2, the discount factor (0.9) would reduce my realized value to 0.9 × 771 = 693.9, which is still less than my guaranteed outside offer of 724.

The current offer on the table gives me a raw value of:
• 3 × 21 = 63  
• 2 × 83 = 166  
• 1 × 10 = 10  
• 1 × 9 = 9  
• 1 × 85 = 85  

Total = 63 + 166 + 10 + 9 + 85 = 333, and after discounting to Round 2 I would get 0.9 × 333 = 299.7.

Since no counteroffer I can propose in Round 2 would achieve a better outcome (even the best-case share falls short of my outside offer), it is best for me to walk away and secure the outside offer value of 724.

{"action": "WALK"}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
• The current offer would give me only 1 unit of item4. With my value of 98 per unit for item4, that’s 98. When discounted in round 2 (×0.9) the deal is worth about 88, which is far below my outside option of 1091.
• In order to beat my outside option in round 2 a deal must yield me an undiscounted value of at least roughly 1091/0.9 ≈ 1213. Since the maximum possible value (if I got every item) is 1292, I can only afford to concede up to 1292 – 1213 = about 79 value points (in terms of my own private values).
• I want to keep nearly all of the high‐value items (item1, item3, and item4 – whose values are 83, 84, and 98 respectively for me) and only give up parts of the items that are low in my valuation. My value for item2 is only 16 per unit and for item5 it is 24 per unit.
• One reasonable plan is to concede 3 units of item2 (3 × 16 = 48) and 1 unit of item5 (1 × 24 = 24), for a total “loss” of 48 + 24 = 72. This keeps my share at a raw value of 1292 – 72 = 1220; discounted in round 2 that gives 1220 × 0.9 = 1098, which safely beats my outside offer.
• In my counteroffer I would be “offering” to give Player 2 3 units of item2 and 1 unit of item5, keeping for myself the remaining items. This deal gives me high‐value items while conceding only a minimal amount in terms of my private value.

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 3, 0, 0, 1]}

round_data.response:
My reasoning is as follows:

• We have 5 item types with totals: 3, 4, 4, 3, and 7 respectively. My private per‐unit values are very high on items 1 (58), 2 (60), 4 (84) and 5 (98), while item 3 is very low value (5). It makes sense to avoid giving away the items I value most.

• To start the negotiation, I want an offer that gives Player 2 sufficient “incentive” (so that their expected deal is competitive with their own outside offer) while allowing me to keep a very high-value bundle. I can give them all 4 units of item 3 (which I value so little) and a modest number of units from one of the highest total-count items (item 5) so that they receive some additional “cake” to improve their potential deal value.

• With the offer [0, 0, 4, 0, 3], Player 2 would get:
  – 0 of item 1 (total 3 remain with me)
  – 0 of item 2 (total 4 remain with me)
  – all 4 units of item 3 (which, given my low value of 5 per unit, I’m happy to cede)
  – 0 of item 4 (I keep all 3 units)
  – 3 units of item 5 (so I keep the remaining 4 of item 5)
	
• This gives me a bundle that yields a total value of:
  item 1: 3×58 = 174,
  item 2: 4×60 = 240,
  item 4: 3×84 = 252,
  item 5: 4×98 = 392,
  total = 174 + 240 + 252 + 392 = 1058,
which is well above my outside offer of 484.

• Meanwhile, Player 2 gets 4 units of item 3 and 3 units of item 5. Even though I do not know their private values, this bundle provides them some items. By including part of item 5 (a moderately large concession from the highest‐valued category) along with all of item 3, the offer may be attractive enough to start a serious negotiation.

Given these considerations, I will make the following initial counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 0, 4, 0, 3]}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
• My objective is to get a deal worth more than my outside offer of 326 and to delay as little as possible (since discounting will reduce payoffs in later rounds).
• I value the items as follows: item 1 (31), item 2 (15), item 3 (4), item 4 (84), and item 5 (98). Hence my high‐valued items are items 4 and 5, and I want to keep most of those.
• At the same time I must give Player 2 enough so that in their eyes (with unknown private values) the deal is at least as attractive as their outside offer.
• A reasonable strategy is to concede more of the items that I value less (items 2 and 3) and a modest share of the others so that Player 2 sees benefit.
• For example, if I offer Player 2: 2 units of item 1 (giving up a moderate value), all of item 2’s 6 units might be too many so I choose a moderate share (3), similarly 2 units of item 3 (which I value low), 1 unit of item 4 (keeping most of the high‐value item) and 3 units of item 5 (again keeping most).
• This yields a counteroffer where Player 2 would receive:
  – Item 1: 2 (out of 5)
  – Item 2: 3 (out of 6)
  – Item 3: 2 (out of 4)
  – Item 4: 1 (out of 4)
  – Item 5: 3 (out of 9)
• Under this division I keep:
  – Item 1: 3, item 2: 3, item 3: 2, item 4: 3, and item 5: 6.
• My own value for my share is: 3×31 + 3×15 + 2×4 + 3×84 + 6×98 = 93 + 45 + 8 + 252 + 588 = 986, which is well above my outside offer.
• Although I don’t know Player 2’s private values, by giving up a modest share of the higher‐valued items while conceding more of the lower‐valued ones I try to leave them an incentive (possibly above their outside offer) while maximizing my own outcome.
• Therefore, my initial counteroffer is as follows.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [2,3,2,1,3]}

round_data.response:
I've analyzed our situation as follows. We know our private values (item1=71, item2=22, item3=35, item4=7, item5=85) and that the available quantities are [6, 4, 4, 2, 5]. (Remember that if we offer an allocation “O” (a list [n1, n2, n3, n4, n5]), that means we are giving those quantities of the items to Player 2 and keeping the remaining amounts for ourselves.) Our total “max‐value” (if we kept everything) is 1093, so our deal value when we obtain a division where our share is [6–n1, 4–n2, 4–n3, 2–n4, 5–n5] becomes

  Value = 71*(6–n1) + 22*(4–n2) + 35*(4–n3) + 7*(2–n4) + 85*(5–n5)
        = 1093 – [71*n1 + 22*n2 + 35*n3 + 7*n4 + 85*n5].

We have an outside offer of 882, so we must ensure any deal we agree to gives us at least that value (ideally, more) given no delay (round 1 discount factor is 1).

Because our strengths lie in items that have high personal value (notably item1 and item5) and we value items2 and item4 less, a common negotiation tactic is to offer those items fully to Player 2 to “buy” their acceptance while we keep the items that matter most to us. (Item3 is moderate so we might share it.)

For example, if we propose giving Player 2 all of item2 (4 units) and item4 (2 units), then we efficiently hand over items that are relatively less valuable to us. To further entice them, we might give a modest share of item3. One candidate division is to offer:
  Offer to P2 = [0 units of item1, 4 units of item2, 2 units of item3, 2 units of item4, 0 units of item5].

Then our allocation would be:
  Item1: 6 – 0 = 6,
  Item2: 4 – 4 = 0,
  Item3: 4 – 2 = 2,
  Item4: 2 – 2 = 0,
  Item5: 5 – 0 = 5.

Our resulting value would be:
  6×71 + 2×35 + 5×85 = 426 + 70 + 425 = 921,
which is above our fallback of 882.

Even though we don’t know Player 2’s private values, giving them a full share of lower‐valued items (from our standpoint) and a modest share of a moderate item should help in making the offer acceptable to them (since they must compare it to their outside option). This division is valid, and from our perspective it maximizes our internal value while leaving Player 2 with what might be enough incentive to accept.

Thus, my action this round will be to make the following counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 4, 2, 2, 0]}

round_data.response:
I'm reasoning as follows:

1. My total value if I took everything is 460, and my outside offer is 456. In a deal, I receive the value of my allocation exactly given by (total value of items I keep). Since the division proposal is expressed by how many items I give to Player 2, my own payoff is the total value of all items (460) minus the loss from giving away items based on my private values.

2. To improve upon my fallback (456), I must guarantee an outcome strictly above 456. This means I can sacrifice at most 4 points in my own value. Looking at my value per unit—
  • item1: 17,
  • item2: 3,
  • item3: 63,
  • item4: 19,
  • item5: 56—
the only item where even one unit costs me less than or equal to 4 points is item2 (costs 3 per unit).

3. Thus, if I try to “concede” by giving away one unit of item2, my own value becomes 460 – 3 = 457, which is barely above my outside offer. However, Player 2’s outside offer is drawn uniformly between 1 and the total value they have for all items. Given the likely high total and the uniform draw, Player 2 would usually expect a reservation value significantly higher than what one unit of item2 (with an average value around 51 from a uniform [1,101] distribution) would provide. In effect, if I give only one unit of item2, it is highly likely that Player 2’s payoff from my offer (≈51 on average) will not meet their fallback value.

4. Any more generous offer (giving away additional items) would cost me too much; for example, giving away two units of item2 would cost me 6 points, leaving me with only 454 value – worse than my fallback. Similarly, conceding in any other item would cost too much.

5. Given these constraints, a deal acceptable to Player 2 would force me to sacrifice too much value relative to my strong outside alternative of 456. Hence, it appears that any division that gives Player 2 a realistic chance to accept would reduce my share below my fallback.

In conclusion, my best strategy at this stage is to WALK away and secure my outside offer of 456 rather than risk proposing an offer that would either be rejected or force me to give away too much value.

{"action": "WALK"}

round_data.response:
I want to make sure that if the deal is reached in round 1 I get a payoff that beats the 507 I’m guaranteed with my outside offer and also “sell” enough to Player 2 so that he will consider accepting. My own value for each item is

  item 1: 22  (3 available)
  item 2: 29  (4 available)
  item 3: 16  (2 available)
  item 4: 33  (4 available)
  item 5: 92  (5 available)

If I took all items I would get 806. My outside offer is 507 so that is my “disagreement” level.

I want my eventual share (the items I keep) to be worth more than 507. At the same time I want to give Player 2 enough that—given that his private values and outside offer (drawn roughly uniformly from 1 up to his total value) are unknown—he sees the proposal as at least as attractive as “walking away.”

One simple idea is to “allocate” the items so that I keep almost everything of my highest‐value good (item 5, at 92 per unit) and I “sell” him a good share of the other items by giving him his full (or nearly full) allocation of those items that are less valuable to me. For example, consider the following proposal:
 • Give Player 2 all 3 units of item 1
 • Give him 3 of the 4 units of item 2 (so I keep 1)
 • Give him both units of item 3
 • Give him 3 of the 4 units of item 4 (so I keep 1)
 • Give him 0 of item 5 (I keep all 5)

My resulting share is then: [0, 1, 0, 1, 5]. Let’s check my value:
 • Item 1: 0 × 22 = 0
 • Item 2: 1 × 29 = 29
 • Item 3: 0 × 16 = 0
 • Item 4: 1 × 33 = 33
 • Item 5: 5 × 92 = 460
  Total = 29 + 33 + 460 = 522

That gives me 522—above my outside offer of 507. (In round 1 there is no discount so the full 522 applies.)

For Player 2, he would receive: [3, 3, 2, 3, 0]. Even though his specific values aren’t known, if we assume his per‐unit values are drawn from a similar uniform distribution the overall offered bundle (roughly 11 units) should “feel” competitive compared to a draw from his own outside offer distribution.

Thus I will make the following counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [3, 3, 2, 3, 0]}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
1. We start in round 1 with no offer on the table. As Player 1 we must propose an initial division of the items.
2. The total items available are: 
  • Item 1: 3 units 
  • Item 2: 6 units 
  • Item 3: 6 units 
  • Item 4: 7 units 
  • Item 5: 3 units
3. Our private values per unit are high for item 1 (97) and item 5 (41), and comparatively lower for items 2 (35), 3 (28), and 4 (27). This means we prefer to keep a larger number of items 1 and 5 for ourselves.
4. Our outside offer guarantees 276 value, so any deal we accept must yield us more than that. At the same time, to have the other player accept our deal in round 1 (when there is no discount) we need to leave them an offer that they will likely view as better than their own alternative.
5. A standard starting point in bargaining problems is a “fair‐looking” split that does not leave the other side feeling too shortchanged. Although we lack information on Player 2’s private values, a near–balanced split makes acceptance more likely.
6. One way to do this is to base our counteroffer on a division that gives player 2 roughly one “unit” of concession in each category that is not overly costly for us. For example, we can offer player 2:
  – 1 unit of item 1 (so that we keep 2 units of the highest–valued item)
  – 3 units of item 2 (keeping 3)
  – 3 units of item 3 (keeping 3)
  – 3 units of item 4 (keeping 4, since there are 7 in total)
  – 1 unit of item 5 (keeping 2)
7. Under this proposal our own bundle would be:
  • Item 1: 2 units → 2×97 = 194
  • Item 2: 3 units → 3×35 = 105 
  • Item 3: 3 units → 3×28 = 84 
  • Item 4: 4 units → 4×27 = 108 
  • Item 5: 2 units → 2×41 = 82 
  Total = 194 + 105 + 84 + 108 + 82 = 573, which is well above our outside offer.
8. This division leaves Player 2 with:
  • Item 1: 1 unit
  • Item 2: 3 units
  • Item 3: 3 units
  • Item 4: 3 units
  • Item 5: 1 unit
While we do not know their exact values, this offer appears reasonably balanced and gives them a significant share in multiple item types.
9. Therefore, as our initial counteroffer we propose that we give Player 2 the bundle [1, 3, 3, 3, 1] (which represents the number of each item being offered to them).

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 3, 3, 3, 1]}

round_data.response:
Step‐by‐step reasoning:
1. I note that my private values are high for items 3, 4, and 5 while being relatively lower for items 1 and 2. Thus I prefer to keep most of item 3 and item 5.
2. I also have an outside offer of 75 (guaranteed) so any deal must give me considerably more than that. I want to maximize my value, while trying to offer Player 2 just enough so that his deal is at least as attractive relative to his unknown outside offer.
3. In a first‐round move I have a first-mover advantage. I therefore aim for a relatively aggressive division in which I keep most of the high‐value goods for me (e.g. items 3, 4, and 5) and concede only a few low–to–moderate valued units (from my perspective) of items where I care the least.
4. Based on these considerations I propose giving Player 2 only 1 unit of item 1 and 2 units of item 5. Even though I must guess what Player 2’s private values might be, this minimal offer is designed to be just barely above a likely outside alternative without costing me too much.
5. In this offer, Player 2 receives:
  • Item 1: 1 (of 5 available)
  • Item 2: 0 (of 2)
  • Item 3: 0 (of 1)
  • Item 4: 0 (of 4)
  • Item 5: 2 (of 7)
   I would keep the remaining items for myself. This results in a high personal payoff (e.g. 4 units of item 1, 2 of item 2, 1 of item 3, 4 of item 4, and 5 of item 5) while still offering Player 2 a bundle that may be competitive with his outside offer.

Thus, my response is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 0, 0, 0, 2]}

My analysis is as follows:
• The current offer gives you 3 units of item 1 and 7 units of item 2 – with your per‐unit values of 34 and 48, respectively that gives you a total of 3×34 + 7×48 = 102 + 336 = 438.
• Compared to your outside (fallback) offer of 150, 438 is much more favorable.
• Any counteroffer made in round 1 risks dragging the negotiation into later rounds where the discount factor (γ = 0.9) reduces the overall value. In round 2 the value of any deal would be multiplied by 0.9 (and even lower later).
• Given that the current offer already gives you a secure outcome of 438 (un-discounted), it is not worth risking any delay or potential misalignment in a counteroffer.
Therefore, the best course is to ACCEPT the current offer.

round_data.response:
I want to “anchor” our proposal by ensuring that Player 2 gets just enough value so that—given his secret per‐unit values and his outside offer guarantee—he is at least indifferent to waiting (or “walking away”) rather than rejecting our proposal. (Recall that his outside offer is unknown to us, but by symmetry it is drawn from a similar pool so it might not be huge relative to the full‐surplus value, and his expected per‐unit “worth” is roughly in the middle of 1 and 101.) Our goal is then to claim as much of the high‐value (“expensive”) items for ourselves while conceding only a few “cheaper” items to induce acceptance immediately (and so avoid any discount penalty).

Our items (with our values) are:
 item 1: 7 units, value 40 each
 item 2: 5 units, value 37 each
 item 3: 4 units, value 23 each
 item 4: 3 units, value 24 each
 item 5: 6 units, value 49 each

If we took everything we would get 923 in value. However, if our proposal is rejected the game ends (or we would lose time and discounting in later rounds) and our fallback is only 115. Thus we want a deal that gives Player 2 at least roughly 115 in “value” when he evaluates the items—without giving away too much of the items we highly prize.

Since items 3 and 4 are the ones with the lowest per‐unit value for us (23 and 24, respectively) it makes sense to concede in these categories. In order for Player 2 to “expect” a deal worth above his outside offer (which we expect to be in the 100–150 range on average), we want him to receive around 3 units in total. Conceding one unit in each of items 3 and 4 gives him 2 units, but that might fall short if his “private numbers” are on the lower side; so we add one more unit from item 3 (the cheapest for us).

Thus we propose to offer Player 2:
 item 1: 0 units
 item 2: 0 units
 item 3: 2 units
 item 4: 1 unit
 item 5: 0 units

In this case our remaining allocation is:
 item 1: 7, item 2: 5, item 3: 4–2 = 2, item 4: 3–1 = 2, item 5: 6

That gives us a total value of:
 7×40 = 280, 5×37 = 185, 2×23 = 46, 2×24 = 48, 6×49 = 294.
  Sum = 280 + 185 + 46 + 48 + 294 = 853,
which is far above our fallback of 115, while (given reasonable expectations about Player 2’s numbers) giving him an offer that is likely to clear his own outside benchmark.

Thus, my move in round 1 is to offer the following division to Player 2:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 0, 2, 1, 0]}

round_data.response:
I want to explain my thinking briefly (though note that in an actual negotiation I wouldn’t reveal all internal reasoning):

Currently the offer on the table would give me a value of 
  0·40 + 2·26 + 3·91 + 0·47 + 3·96 = 613,
which is well below my outside option of 829. That means accepting now would be a real loss.

I therefore must counteroffer. In our game a counteroffer is given by a list [n₁,n₂, …] meaning “I offer you these many units of each item” and I get the remainder (for each item, total available minus what I offer you). My goal is to ensure that (1) my share (the remainder) in my private valuation exceeds 829 (since that’s what I guarantee if I simply WALK), and (2) I leave you (Player 1) with something that – hopefully – is acceptable to you given you must compare it to your own outside option. In other words, I’m designing a division that (by my own view) gives me a good value while giving you a possibility of a deal that is not “free‐money” for me.

I have a total of 3,4,3,2,8 units. By offering you [3,3,0,1,2] units, you would get:
  Item 1: 3 units,
  Item 2: 3 units,
  Item 3: 0 units,
  Item 4: 1 unit,
  Item 5: 2 units.
That leaves me with:
  Item 1: 0 units (3–3),
  Item 2: 1 unit (4–3),
  Item 3: 3 units (3–0),
  Item 4: 1 unit (2–1),
  Item 5: 6 units (8–2).

My value for that allocation is computed as:
  0·40 + 1·26 + 3·91 + 1·47 + 6·96 
    = 0 + 26 + 273 + 47 + 576 
    = 922.
This is above my fallback value of 829, and so it secures me a better outcome if accepted immediately (and without the delay discount).

While I cannot know your private values, I am trying to offer you a nontrivial package that might seem attractive enough compared to your own outside option. Keeping in mind that each player’s outside offer is drawn from a wide range, this balanced‐ish offer is an attempt to induce early agreement.

Thus, my action is to make the following counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [3,3,0,1,2]}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:

We know our private per‐unit values are [5, 69, 66, 89, 61] and the total amounts available are [1, 4, 3, 8, 3]. Thus if we took everything we’d get a total raw value of 1374. In round 2 any deal is discounted by 0.9 so if we made a deal giving us raw value X the effective value is 0.9·X. Also our outside offer gives us 1149 for sure. This means that to improve over our outside option, we need
  0.9·(our share’s raw value) > 1149  or  our share’s raw value > 1149/0.9 ≈ 1277.
Thus, the maximum concession we can “afford” (i.e. the amount of item value we leave to Player 2) is about 1374 − 1277 = 97 (in our own valuation).

The current offer on the table would give us [1,3,1,5,1] (utility 784, discounted to about 705.6) which is far below 1149. Therefore we must make a counteroffer in which we claim nearly every valuable unit; in other words, we must “keep” most of the items so that our own undiscounted value remains at least 1277.

Choosing among possible minimal concessions (each item “costs” us its per‐unit value), we notice that item1 is “cheap” (5 value per unit) and item2 is moderate (69 value per unit). For example, if we offer Player 2 the following:
  • all of item1 (1 unit, costing us 5) and
  • one unit of item2 (1 unit, costing us 69),
then our total concession is 5 + 69 = 74.
Our remainder would be:
  item1: 0  (item total 1 − 1)
  item2: 3  (4 − 1)
  item3: 3  (all 3)
  item4: 8  (all 8)
  item5: 3  (all 3)
This gives us a raw value of:
  0·5 + 3·69 + 3·66 + 8·89 + 3·61 = 0 + 207 + 198 + 712 + 183 = 1300.
Discounted by 0.9 we get 0.9 × 1300 = 1170 – which is just above our outside offer of 1149.

Even though this counteroffer gives Player 2 only two items ([item1, item2] = [1, 1, 0, 0, 0]), it is the best we can do to bring our own effective value above our reservation. (Any additional concession would lower our value below the threshold while offering little extra incentive to Player 2.) Therefore, to maximize our outcome we propose to give Player 2 [1,1,0,0,0].

Thus my final action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1,1,0,0,0]}.

round_data.response:
I want to propose an offer that is aggressive from my side while “buying” acceptance from Player 2. My own values are much higher for items 2, 3, and 5 (95, 70, and 77 respectively) than for item 1 (3); so I want to keep all of items 2, 3, and 5 for myself. By contrast, although I do not know Player 2’s exact valuations, all five items are drawn from a similar distribution for them. In expectation their per‐unit value is about 51, so giving them the entire stock of items in which I have very little value will likely provide them with a bundle comparable to (or better than) their outside offer. In our case, my fallback (outside offer) is 261, and if we estimate Player 2’s total (expected) is roughly 714, their outside offer is roughly half that (around 357). 

Thus, if I give Player 2 all 7 units of item 1 (worth about 7×51 ≈ 357 in expectation) and the single unit of item 4 (worth ≈51 in expectation), then on expectation they would receive about 408, which should be attractive compared with their outside option. Meanwhile I keep:
• All 3 units of item 2 (3×95 = 285)
• All 2 units of item 3 (2×70 = 140)
• All 1 unit of item 5 (1×77 = 77)

That gives me a total value of 285+140+77 = 502, which far exceeds my fallback value of 261. (Also note that we are still in round 1, so the full value is realized with no discount.) 

This division is “risky” from my point of view only if Player 2 happens to have an unusually low value for items 1 or 4 relative to their outside offer, but given the random draws and that players’ outside values are drawn from the total value range, the offer should seem fair to Player 2. 

Thus my initial offer as Player 1 is to give Player 2 all of item 1 (7 units) and item 4 (1 unit), and I keep the rest.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [7, 0, 0, 1, 0]}

round_data.response:
I want to make sure any deal I accept gives me a present‐value (after discount) that is at least as good as my “outside offer” of 402. In round 2 the discount factor is 0.9 so any negotiated deal gives me 0.9×(nominal value). In other words, to beat my outside option the deal’s nominal value must be at least roughly 402/0.9 ≈ 447 points in my valuation.

My private values are:
 • item 1: 63 • item 2: 36 • item 3: 94 • item 4: 87 • item 5: 40

The total available items are: [3, 3, 0, 3, 3]. With an offer vector X (the amounts I give to Player 1) the remainder I receive is (total – X). My nominal value is therefore:
  678 – [63·(x₁) + 36·(x₂) + 87·(x₄) + 40·(x₅)]
(since item 3 is 0, x₃ = 0).

I want a counteroffer that leaves me with nominal value at least 447. One good “selfish” idea is to keep the items I value most (item 1 at 63 and item 4 at 87) and concede on the lower‐valued items (items 2 and 5). For example, if I offer to give Player 1 all of items 2 and 5—that is, make the counteroffer:
  [0, 3, 0, 0, 3]
then my share is exactly:
  [3, 0, 0, 3, 0].

My nominal value becomes:
  3×63 + 3×87 = 189 + 261 = 450,
which, after discounting (0.9×450 = 405) beats my outside offer of 402 by a small margin.
This counteroffer “squeezes” the deal to my narrow benefit while leaving less‐valued items to Player 1. (Player 1’s own offers in earlier rounds—especially giving away item 1 or item 4—suggest he might accept getting full amounts of items 2 and 5 instead.)

Thus, I will make the counteroffer [0, 3, 0, 0, 3].

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 3, 0, 0, 3]}

round_data.response:
I want a deal that beats my fallback of 392 (which is not discounted) when multiplied by the discount factor (0.81) since we’re in round 3. In any deal the raw value I “earn” from my items will be multiplied by 0.81. That means I need to secure raw value V for my items so that 0.81·V > 392, i.e. V must be at least about 484. (Since 392/0.81 ≈ 484.) If I took everything I’d get 561; so the maximum “concession” I can afford to give Player 2 (measured in my own per‐unit item values) is 561 – 484 ≈ 77 (points).

The current offer on the table would give me items [0, 3, 0, 0, 3] for a raw value of 3·90 + 3·43 = 270 + 129 = 399 – far below the 484 needed.

Thus I want to propose a counteroffer in which I “give” Player 2 only items that cost me no more than 77 raw points. Because my own values are lowest for item 1 (11 per unit), a natural idea is to let Player 2 have all units of item 1. That gives 3 × 11 = 33 points. I then have about 77 – 33 = 44 raw points “budget” left for a concession; neither item 2 (90) nor items 4 or 5 (43 each) are cheap, so I can only give one extra unit of either a 43‐point item. Choosing which of item 4 or item 5 to give can be guided by Player 2’s earlier behavior. In both rounds, they offered me [0, 3, 0, 0, 3] – meaning they kept item 1 and item 4. To keep them happy (and assuming they value item 4 highly), I choose to let them have 1 unit of item 4 along with all of item 1. 

Then my counteroffer (what I give to Player 2) becomes:
 Item 1: 3 units,
 Item 2: 0,
 Item 3: 0,
 Item 4: 1 unit,
 Item 5: 0.

That results in me receiving the remainder: 
 Item 1: 0,
 Item 2: 3,
 Item 3: 0,
 Item 4: 3–1 = 2,
 Item 5: 3.
My resulting raw value is:
 3×90 (item 2) + 2×43 (item 4) + 3×43 (item 5) = 270 + 86 + 129 = 485.
Discounted to round 3 outcome: 485×0.81 ≈ 392.85, which narrowly beats my fallback of 392.

Thus, I propose the following counteroffer:

round_data.response:
I want to make an opening offer that gives the opponent a “minimal” concession while allowing me to keep as many high‐value items (from my perspective) as possible. I value item 1 at 96 and item 3 at 79 per unit – so I want to keep the entire supply of these (4 and 3 units, respectively) for myself. Items for which my private values are lower (item 2 at 14 and item 4 at 18) are natural candidates for a full concession. For item 5 I value it at 63 so I would want to keep most of it, but I might need to concede at least a little to make the offer acceptable to Player 2.

The full pool is:
• Item 1: 4 units
• Item 2: 9 units
• Item 3: 3 units
• Item 4: 3 units
• Item 5: 3 units

Thus one possibility is to offer Player 2 all of items 2 and 4 and a minimal concession on item 5 (1 unit), while keeping all of items 1 and 3 and 2 out of 3 units of item 5. In that case, the division would be:
• Offer to Player 2: 
 – Item 1: 0 units
 – Item 2: 9 units
 – Item 3: 0 units
 – Item 4: 3 units
 – Item 5: 1 unit
• Which leaves me with:
 – Item 1: 4 units
 – Item 2: 0 units
 – Item 3: 3 units
 – Item 4: 0 units
 – Item 5: 2 units

My own payoff from the remaining items would be:
• Item 1: 4 × 96 = 384
• Item 3: 3 × 79 = 237
• Item 5: 2 × 63 = 126
Total = 384 + 237 + 126 = 747

This is well above my outside offer of 382 and makes me very happy. Meanwhile, Player 2 is receiving all of the items that I see as low in value (items 2 and 4) plus a little bit from item 5. Given that Player 2’s private values are drawn uniformly, it is likely that this package will appeal to them as it might be worth a good amount on their side (or at least above their reservation, once they compare with their outside offer). 

So my chosen opening offer (counteroffer) is to give Player 2 [0, 9, 0, 3, 1].

round_data.response:
My current offer (“offer on the table”) would give me items [0, 9, 0, 3, 1]. With my private values (46, 98, 62, 96, 99) that yields a total value of

  0·46 + 9·98 + 0·62 + 3·96 + 1·99 = 882 + 288 + 99 = 1269.

However, I have a secure outside option worth 1285. So accepting the current offer would get me less than my fallback. In a counteroffer I must make sure that my resulting allocation (the leftover items after I offer something to Player 1) is worth at least 1285 for me—and preferably more, so that if a deal is reached I improve relative to my outside option.

Recall that any counteroffer is made by specifying how many units (of each item) I give to Player 1. The items I then get are the remainders:
  For item i: my allocation = (total units) – (units given in my offer).

The totals are: item1: 4, item2: 9, item3: 3, item4: 3, item5: 3.

Player 1’s initial offer in Round 1 gives them
  [4, 0, 3, 0, 2]
(where I received [0, 9, 0, 3, 1]).
That division would leave me with value 1269 (<1285). I need a small improvement.
I note that if I reduce the amount I give Player 1 on an item that I value modestly—say item 1 (worth 46 for me)—I can “steal” one unit for myself. For example, if I change my counteroffer so that I offer only 3 units of item 1 (instead of 4 as in the original division), then my share for item 1 becomes 4 – 3 = 1 unit instead of 0.
All other items can remain as in their original split. My new allocation would then be:
  Item 1: 1 unit
  Item 2: 9 units
  Item 3: 0 units
  Item 4: 3 units
  Item 5: 1 unit

Then my total value is:
  1·46 + 9·98 + 0·62 + 3·96 + 1·99 = 46 + 882 + 0 + 288 + 99 = 1305.

This 1305 is safely above my fallback of 1285, and the change compared to the original proposal is minimal (only taking one unit of item 1 from Player 1). Though I don’t know Player 1’s private values, this slight adjustment should be less aggressive and makes my position better relative to my fallback.

Thus, my response is to propose a counteroffer that gives Player 1: [3, 0, 3, 0, 2].

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [3, 0, 3, 0, 2]}

round_data.response:
I note that accepting the current offer would give me an allocation of [1, 4, 1, 0, 1]. My private values imply a deal‐value of
  1×44 + 4×67 + 1×45 + 0×74 + 1×91 = 44 + 268 + 45 + 0 + 91 = 448,
which is lower than my outside option of 503. In order to do at least as well as my outside offer (and ideally do better), I want my final allocation (which is the total available minus what I give to Player 1) to have a total value of at least 503. In my numbers the total value of all items is 624 so I can potentially do better. Notice that items 2, 3, and 5 are all fully available in one unit or few units and they are highly valuable to me (67, 45, and 91 respectively). In order to “earn” enough value, I must obtain these and also a portion of item 1. In fact, if I take all of items 2, 3, and 5 I get
  4×67 + 1×45 + 1×91 = 268 + 45 + 91 = 404.
That leaves me needing at least 99 more value. Since each unit of item 1 is worth 44 for me, I must have at least 3 units of item 1 (3×44 = 132) to be above 503. One way to obtain that is to ensure my own allocation is: item 1: 3, item 2: 4, item 3: 1, item 5: 1 (item 4 is not present). That yields a value of 3×44 + 268 + 45 + 91 = 132 + 268 + 45 + 91 = 536, which is above my outside option.

Since the counteroffer is given as what I give to Player 1, my allocation will be the total minus that offer. The totals are [5, 4, 1, 0, 1]. To obtain my desired allocation of [3, 4, 1, 0, 1] I must offer Player 1 the remainder:
  Item 1: 5 – 3 = 2, item 2: 4 – 4 = 0, item 3: 1 – 1 = 0, item 4: 0 – 0 = 0, item 5: 1 – 1 = 0,
which gives the counteroffer [2, 0, 0, 0, 0].

Although Player 1’s initial offer was [1, 4, 1, 0, 1] (giving them [4, 0, 0, 0, 0]), I am raising my own share (aiming for 536 in my value) to beat my outside option. I trust that offering only 2 of item 1 to Player 1 may be sufficiently attractive (since the outside offers are uncertain) especially given that waiting further would incur a discount. 

Thus, I will respond with the counteroffer that gives Player 1 [2, 0, 0, 0, 0]. 

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [2, 0, 0, 0, 0]}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
• If we accept the current offer, we receive [3, 0, 0, 8, 3] for items 1–5. Computing our value:
 item 1: 3×30 = 90
 item 2: 0×5 = 0
 item 3: 0×64 = 0
 item 4: 8×29 = 232
 item 5: 3×3 = 9
Total = 90 + 232 + 9 = 331, which is less than our outside offer of 482. So accepting is not good for us.

• As Player 2, we can make a counteroffer. In our counteroffer we propose how many items we give to Player 1, and we keep the remaining items. Our total full value (if we got all items) is 657. Thus if we receive value V then the “cost” (i.e. the value we give to Player 1) is 657 – V. To do at least as well as our outside offer, we need V ≥ 482. Choosing V = 482 means we can “afford” to give away 657 – 482 = 175 value (by our own valuation).

• We now choose a combination of items x = [x1, x2, x3, x4, x5] (each within the supply limits) to satisfy:
 30∙x1 + 5∙x2 + 64∙x3 + 29∙x4 + 3∙x5 = 175.
A possible solution is:
 x1 = 1 → contributes 30;
 x4 = 5 → contributes 5×29 = 145;
 and x2, x3, x5 = 0.
This gives 30 + 145 = 175, exactly.

• With our counteroffer of [1, 0, 0, 5, 0] to Player 1, our retained items become:
 Item 1: 6 – 1 = 5
 Item 2: 7 – 0 = 7
 Item 3: 3 – 0 = 3
 Item 4: 8 – 5 = 3
 Item 5: 6 – 0 = 6
Our value then is:
 5×30 + 7×5 + 3×64 + 3×29 + 6×3
 = 150 + 35 + 192 + 87 + 18 = 482.
This equals our reservation (outside) value, ensuring that if Player 1 accepts now we are at least as well off as walking away, and the offer might be attractive to Player 1 as well.

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 0, 0, 5, 0]}

At the same time I must give Player 2 enough items – typically those that are less beneficial to me – to make the deal attractive compared to their unknown outside offer.
3. With item1 being my least valued, I can give Player 2 all 4 units, and then add a small share of a couple of lower–but not too low–value items (items 4 and 5) to strengthen their incentive to accept.
4. One offer that strikes a balance is to give Player 2 all 4 of item1, plus 1 unit each of item4 and item5. This leaves me with all of items 2 and 3 (both 5 units each), and 5 units each of items 4 and 5. This allocation gives me a very high intrinsic value while still providing Player 2 with something.
5. Thus, my initial offer is to give Player 2: 4 of item1, 0 of item2, 0 of item3, 1 of item4, and 1 of item5.

My action is:

round_data.response:
I want to keep the items I value most (items 1 and 4, which are worth 100 each to me) and try to concede on items I care less about (items 2, 3, and 5). In proposing an offer, I must remember that my fallback (my outside offer) guarantees me 588, so I want to do better than that. By keeping all of item 1 (2 units) and all of item 4 (4 units) for myself I secure 2×100 + 4×100 = 600 points from those alone. I can also afford to allow myself only half of items where I’m less efficient (items 2, 3, and 5) so that my share is still high. For example, if I offer Player 2 all of item 2 (2 units), half of item 3 (2 of 4 units) and half of item 5 (2 of 4 units), then I receive the rest. My own share would then be: 
 Item 1: 2 (worth 2×100 = 200)
 Item 2: 0 (0×22 = 0)
 Item 3: 2 (2×39 = 78)
 Item 4: 4 (4×100 = 400)
 Item 5: 2 (2×29 = 58)
For a total of 200 + 78 + 400 + 58 = 736 which is well above my outside offer of 588.

Thus my initial counteroffer (what I give to Player 2) is to let them have:
 Item 1: 0  
 Item 2: 2  
 Item 3: 2  
 Item 4: 0  
 Item 5: 2  

This division leaves me with the remaining items, and it is a valid initial division offer.

    You are Player 2 and the other agent is Player 1.
    There are 5 types of items, called item 1 through item 5.
    There are 2 units of item 1, 2 units of item 2, 4 units of item 3, 4 units of item 4, 4 units of item 5 to divide.
    Both you and Player 1 have a private value per unit of each item type.
    These values are drawn from a uniform random distribution, ranging from 1 to 101.
    Your private values are 6 for item 1, 46 for item 2, 6 for item 3, 29 for item 4, 47 for item 5.
    You have a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to your total value of all items, which is 432. Player 1 has a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to to their total value of all items.
    Your outside offer value is 332. Your objective is to maximize your value of the outcome of the negotiation game. Remember, you have a guaranteed alternative: your outside offer.

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.
    There is a discount rate gamma = 0.9, such that if the process concludes after r rounds the overall value of the negotiation to each player is their value for the outcome multiplied by gamma to the power (r-1).
    At each round, Player 1 takes an action, followed by Player 2.
    The possible actions are to ACCEPT the other player's current offer (if any), make a COUNTEROFFER, or WALK away.  If the game gets to the last round, and player 2 chooses to make a counteroffer, this is treated as a WALK.
    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.
    The value of an outcome is determined by each player's private values per unit of each item and the quantities they receive in the deal. This value is adjusted by the discount factor, which is used to compute the present value of the negotiation outcome.
    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

round_data.response:
My current offer gives me [1,1,1,2,0], which (by my private values) amounts to 
  item1: 1×79 = 79  
  item2: 1×6 = 6  
  item3: 1×73 = 73  
  item4: 2×38 = 76  
  item5: 0×60 = 0    
for a total of 234. 

Because my outside option is 489 (and note that when the deal is struck in round 1 there is no discount, so any accepted division would give me the full value of my allocated items), 234 is far below my reservation. I could try to counteroffer so that I get a division whose total value (from all items I receive) is above 489. However, to construct a counteroffer I must “give” some items to Player 1, and the counteroffer must be acceptable from their side. (I do not know Player 1’s private values or their outside offer; their expected reservation might be substantially lower than mine, but there’s a risk that offering too little might cause them to hold out, driving the negotiation into further rounds. In later rounds the values would be discounted, and I would risk ending up with less than my guaranteed 489.) 

Since the current offer is well below my reservation and any counteroffer aimed at increasing my share (and thus my value) may be rejected by Player 1—forcing me into further rounds with discounting—I risk ending with less than my safe alternative. 

Given that I have a guaranteed alternative of 489 (which is significantly higher than the 234 currently on offer) and that delaying might worsen the outcome due to the discount rate (0.9 per round), my best course of action is to guarantee my reservation value by walking away.

{"action": "WALK"}
